unnormalised: So, Section 80C, the beloved savior of the salaried middle class, allows you to deduct up to ₹1.5 lakh from your taxable income. It's like that one friend who always bails you out, except instead of pizza money, it's saving you from the clutches of the Income Tax Dept. You cram in your ELSS investments, your LIC premiums, even your kids' tuition fees. It’s basically financial Jenga; pull out too many blocks and the whole thing collapses.

unnormalised: Now, GST, or Goods and Services Tax. A single tax, they said. Simple, they said. It'll be like sunshine and rainbows, they said. What we got was more like a monsoon season in Mumbai – complicated, unpredictable, and leaving you soaked to the bone trying to figure out which rate applies to your samosas. Is it 5%? Is it 12%? Only the GST Council knows! And frankly, they're probably arguing about it as we speak.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole saga of tax audits. If your turnover crosses a certain threshold (I believe it's Rs. 10 Cr. now for some businesses), you need a chartered accountant to give your books the once-over. It’s like having a doctor check your cholesterol, except instead of prescribing statins, they prescribe more spreadsheets. And if you've been a bit "creative" with your accounting, well, let's just say you might need a good lawyer (Adv. Sharma is excellent, I hear).
